cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to financial mathematics, interest measurement, present value calculation, annuity valuation, loan amortization, consumer financing arrangements, bond valuation. The course is aimed at a general audience who will not be continuing in the actuarial science program. Course manuals fee: $30.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mathematics of Finance for Non-Actuaries

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Most of the lectures will be pre-recorded videos posted on Quercus. But there will be at least two live webinars during the semester during the scheduled times. Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus (including Blackboard Collaborate).

cmCourseInfo.description: Interest, discount and present values, as applied to determine prices and values of annuities, mortgages, bonds, equities; loan repayment schedules and consumer finance payments in general; yield rates on investments given the costs on investments. Course manuals fee: $45.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mathematics of Investment & Credit

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. First and last lectures are live webinars using Blackboard Collaborate during the schedule times. The remaining lectures are pre-recorded videos to be posted at least one day before the schedule lecture times. students are required to be present on Quercus for the last 15 minutes of scheduled lecture time (20:45-21:00) for a timed and graded quiz. There are also timed term tests during scheduled lecture times which require students to be on Quercus. Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus (including Blackboard Collaborate).

courses.name: Financial Principles for Actuarial Science I

cmCourseInfo.description: Term structure of interest rates, cashflow duration, convexity and immunization, forward and futures contracts, interest rate swaps, introduction to investment derivatives and hedging strategies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Principles for Actuarial Science I

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be held online at the scheduled times. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions during class or in online office hours. Live webinars will also be recorded for viewing afterwards. More information about the set-up of this course and the available resources and supports will be available in the course syllabus. Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus (including Blackboard Collaborate).

cmCourseInfo.description: Probability theory applied to survival and to costs and risks of life assurances, life annuities, and pensions; analysis of survival distributions; international actuarial notation. Course manuals fee: $35.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Life Contingencies

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. First and last lectures are live webinars using Blackboard Collaborate during the schedule times. The remaining lectures are pre-recorded videos to be posted at least one day before the schedule lecture times. students are required to be present on Quercus for the last 15 minutes of scheduled lecture time (20:45-21:00) for a timed and graded quiz. There are also timed term tests during scheduled lecture times which require students to be on Quercus. Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus (including Blackboard Collaborate).

cmCourseInfo.description: Determination of benefit premium and benefit reserves for life insurance and annuities; analysis of insurance loss random variables; theory of life contingencies for multiple lives. Course manuals fee: $40.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Life Contingencies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ACT240H1 (minimum grade C); ACT245H1 (minimum grade C); ACT247H1 (minimum grade C); (STA257H1,STA261H1); MAT237Y1/MAT257Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid course. Most of the lectures will be pre-recorded videos posted on Quercus. But there will be at least two live webinars during the semester during the scheduled times. Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus (including Blackboard Collaborate).

courses.name: Financial Principles for Actuarial Science II

cmCourseInfo.description: Mathematical theory of financial derivatives, discrete and continuous option pricing models, hedging strategies and exotic option valuation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Financial Principles for Actuarial Science II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ACT240H1 (minimum grade C); ACT245H1 (minimum grade C); ACT247H1 (minimum grade C); (STA257H1,STA261H1); MAT237Y1/MAT257Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures will be held online at the scheduled times. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions during class or in online office hours. More information about the set-up of this course and the available resources and supports will be available in the course syllabus. Students need reliable internet access and the ability to use Quercus (including Blackboard Collaborate), PowerPoint and Excel.
